misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculation
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade-to-letter mapping with conditionals.
misconceptions.student_belief: If I write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them, that will satisfy this programming task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read a single numeric grade (0–100) from the user and, using conditional statements, determine which letter grade (A–F) the number falls into, then print the corresponding letter grade in the specified format.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade: 'Enter x1 and y1:' and 'Enter x2 and y2:'
Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one numeric grade
No conditional (if/else) logic is present to check grade ranges
Output describes the distance between two points instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different exercises (e.g., reusing a distance-formula example) or not carefully mapping the problem specification (grade ranges and letter output) to the program design.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and list explicitly: (1) what input is required (one grade value), (2) what processing is needed (check which numeric range it falls into), and (3) what output format is required (e.g., 'Letter grade: B'). Then design an if/else-if/else chain on the grade value to handle A, B, C, D, and F.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is a standard distance-between-two-points solution with no trace of grade handling, strongly indicating the wrong algorithm was implemented.

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinates and computes a distance; it never reads a single grade or outputs a letter grade, showing the wrong problem was solved.

misconceptions.name: Solved the Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade calculator. Therefore, none of the required grading logic (input, boolean ranges, conditionals, output) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: This code submission satisfies the requirements of Q3, or perhaps I submitted code for a different assignment by mistake.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic to output a corresponding letter grade (A-F). Distance calculation is irrelevant to this task.
symptoms: Input prompts ask for x and y coordinates instead of a single grade.
Program performs distance calculation using the Pythagorean theorem.
Output displays a numeric distance instead of a letter grade.
Missing all conditional logic (if/else if/else) required for grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student failed to match the submitted code to the problem statement. This is a fundamental failure mode, likely due to submitting the incorrect file or fundamentally misinterpreting the assignment after copying unrelated boiler-plate code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3 again. Ensure your inputs, processing steps (using `if-else` statements for grade ranges), and final output all align exactly with the 'Grade Calculator' requirements (reading one input, outputting one letter grade).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Confidence is maximum because the implemented solution is for a completely different problem (Euclidean distance) than the assigned one (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: The code solicits four coordinate inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) and calculates distance 'd', confirming the code addresses a distance problem, not a grade problem.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving the correct problem, or may have copied code from a different assignment without reading the actual requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and mapping it to a letter grade. The student should read one integer/double value, then use conditional statements to determine the appropriate letter grade range.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping grades
Output shows distance calculation instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the problem statement, submitted the wrong file, or copied code from a different assignment without adapting it to the current requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully. The program should: (1) prompt for a single grade value, (2) use if-else statements to check which range it falls into (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.), and (3) print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code and the problem description are completely mismatched. The code calculates distance between points while the problem asks for grade mapping. This is unambiguously the wrong solution.

evidence.note: This code implements a distance calculator using the Euclidean distance formula, not a grade calculator. The problem requires reading a grade (0-100) and outputting a letter grade.
The expected sample output shows a single grade input and letter output. The student's code produces a completely different output format (distance calculation).

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem instead of the specified grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a full program to compute the distance between two points rather than to read a grade and determine its letter grade according to the given scale. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: If my program is syntactically correct and solves a valid problem (like computing the distance between two points), it is acceptable even if it does not match the exact problem description.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each programming question, the program must implement the exact required behavior. In this case, it must read a numeric grade (0–100) and use conditionals to choose and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges. Solving a different problem, even correctly, does not satisfy the task.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade.
Program reads four double values instead of a single integer or double grade.
No conditional statements are present to check grade ranges.
Output reports a distance value, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between problems (e.g., reusing code from a distance-formula exercise) or not carefully re-reading the question requirements before coding.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite the program so it: (1) asks for and reads a single numeric grade, (2) uses an if/else-if/else chain to test the grade against the given ranges (>= 90, >= 80, etc.), and (3) prints the corresponding letter grade. Avoid reusing code from unrelated problems without checking that it matches the current task.
related_concepts: Designing boolean expressions for numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All of the logic and I/O in the submission correspond to a distance-calculation problem and none to a grade-calculation problem, strongly indicating the student solved the wrong task.

evidence.note: The entire program focuses on reading coordinate pairs and computing a distance, with no handling of grades or letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Mismatched Problem Solution (Distance Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of implementing the required Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely believes that the provided code is the solution for the current assignment, possibly due to submitting an answer for a previous question or using an incorrect template.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code reads four double values instead of one integer grade.
Code performs geometric calculation (distance formula) instead of conditional grade assignment.
Output message relates to distance, not letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to address the prompt requirements; possible submission error or misunderstanding of which problem to solve.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and ensure your code specifically addresses those requirements, including reading a single integer input and using if-else logic for grading.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is for calculating Euclidean distance, which has zero overlap with the Grade Calculator problem description.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates distance and prompts for coordinate points, completely ignoring the grade calculation task.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: Student implemented a distance calculator for 2D points instead of a grade calculator. This demonstrates a failure to comprehend or validate the problem requirements before coding.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a geometry/distance problem, not recognizing the actual assignment is for a grade classification problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Before starting to code, the student should carefully read the problem statement and confirm they understand what inputs to read, what processing to perform, and what output to produce. In this case: read a grade (0-100), map it to a letter grade using if/else conditionals, and output the letter.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of 'Enter grade'
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
No conditional logic to check grade ranges
No letter grade output (prints numeric distance)
misconceptions.root_cause: Inadequate problem analysis before implementation. Student may have copied from a previous distance calculator assignment or did not carefully read the problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Create a checklist: (1) What input do I need? (2) What processing/logic? (3) What output? Verify your understanding matches all three requirements before writing code.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (distance calculation) with no evidence of grade-to-letter-grade mapping logic anywhere in the code.

evidence.note: Reads four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade. Wrong input entirely.

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Calculates and outputs Euclidean distance. No letter grade mapping or conditional logic.
